subject: Self Care
title: Blue Light and Screens
description: A micro-lesson that makes Blue Light and Screens usable.

hook.text: Scrolling your phone in bed delays sleep onset by an average of 30 minutes. The light is the weapon.

buildup.text: Blue light wavelengths suppress melatonin production, the hormone that signals your brain to sleep.

discovery.text: Screens mimic daylight. Your circadian clock reads the glow and decides it must still be afternoon.

twist.text: Night mode helps slightly, but the real damage is mental stimulation. Content keeps your brain wired.

climax.text: Put screens away one hour before bed. The melatonin surge that follows is your ticket to faster sleep.

punchline.text: Your phone is a sleep thief. Put it down early.

quiz.question: How does blue light from screens affect sleep?
options: It suppresses melatonin and delays sleep onset
